column3: You'll know her face from talking about cake and cats on the telly, so here's another chance to see the Millican phenomenon in full flight live on stage.
Borderline Theatre Company present Sue Glover's play about liberty, lost love and female empowerment.

column2: BBC SSO: Mussorgsky's Pictures at an Exhibition
column3: Glinka's Valse fantaisie and Shostakovich's Violin Concerto No 1, with guest soloist Boris Brovtsyn, followed by Mussorgsky's tuneful old warhorse. Alexander Vedernikov conducts.

Mahler's ultimately peaceful Symphony No 10 was left unfinished at his death, but it was completed with great sensitivity by the musicologist Deryck Cooke, who was keen that the composer's last testament not be thought to be the awesomely downbeat Symphony No 9. It's presented here with Glazunov's Violin Concerto, featuring soloist James Ehnes. And so Donald Runnicles begins his final season as the BBC SSO's Chief Conductor.

column2: Share Your Stories: The Union Canal
column3: You're invited to share your stories of the Union Canal.
Scotland's unforgettable musical twins return to the stage with their singalong Caledonian anthems.
Paintings inspired by Nan Shepherd's seminal book The Living Mountain.
Ska punk California-based seven-piece.
Amateur choir based in Edinburgh.

column2: Children's Classic Concerts: Magic and Monsters
column3: Owen and Olly are back with a wickedly fun Hallowe'en special, conducted by Jean-Claude Picard and featuring the RSNO Junior Chorus.

Richard Kaufman conducts an evening of music from movies associated with heroes and superheroes, so you can expect the Raiders March, the Superman fanfare, music from Batman and Spiderman . . . but probably not 'Stuck in the Middle with You'.

column2: RSNO: Cole Porter Songbook Anniversary Gala
column3: The Gershwin brothers might have been more influential, Rodgers and Hart might have been more emotional, and Irving Berlin was the daddy of them all but no songwriter from the classic songbook era embodies classiness and wit like Cole Porter. Pianist/conductor Wayne Marshall and Broadway star Kim Criswell celebrate the 125th birthday of the author of 'Night and Day', 'I've Got You Under My Skin', 'They Can't Take That Away From Me', 'Let's Do It' and dozens of other classic songs.
A festival for lovers of all sorts of coffee, from your regular cups of Joe to your skinny-grande mocha-swirl-achino-with-extra-cream sorts, featuring workshops, tastings and demonstrations.

column2: Joe Lycett: That's The Way, A-Ha A-Ha, Joe Lycett
column3: Lycett's latest show is all about the ability to be a wee bit useless in life while trying to figure out what it's all about. He talks about his home town (Birmingham, doncha know?) and about the time he met Kim Kardashian, which is bound to be an interesting story if nothing else.
The singer-songwriter and guitarist from Hitchin plays uplifting folk-rock.
The slick soul funk maestro delivers the evergreen hits all night long.
The London-based five-piece performs progressive metal.
Hard rock quintet from High Wycombe.
The Scotrock stalwarts make the rounds on this greatest hits tour, following their popular 5x5 tour in 2012.
Re-live the sights and sounds of the 60s with the most established Beatles tribute band.

column2: Octonauts and the Deep Sea Volcano Adventure
column3: A deep sea adventure with Captain Barnacles, Kwazii and Peso, in this brand new live stage show.
Cabaret spectacular featuring s fan dancing fantasies, foxy 40s WAF sirens, bubblegum blowing baseball babes and cheesecake pin-ups.
Writer, humorist and wit, brimming with sardonic social observations.
Folk singer-songwriter from County Derry.
The stage moniker of Dublin's Conor O'Brien, a rootsy narrative songwriter whose debut album I Saw The Dead was nominated for the Mercury Music Prize.
Aerosmith tribute band.
Indie-pop and folk with Celtic overtones by Mike Scott and his band of raggle taggle musicians.
Irish singer and titan of crossover Celtic music who has released eleven studio albums.

column2: Kevin Bridges: A Whole Different Story
column3: The biggest name in Scottish stand-up continues his reign with another show packed with astute observations and deathly funny gags.

column2: The Curious Incident Of The Dog In The Night-Time
column3: Simon Stephens's adaptation of the darkly humorous book by Mark Haddon presented by National Theatre.
Twelve acrobats and multidisciplinary artists present an uninterrupted stream of acrobatics, music, images and drawings accompanied by an original musical score and video projections.
The former Soft Cell perv pixie turned torch song crooner and old school cabaret interpreter revisits his 30-year career.
Folky indie pop from Wales.
The popular folk pop chanteuse, known for her work with Fairground Attraction and often called upon to add her voice to other people's records tours her latest album Vagabond.

column2: Andrew Lawrence: Reasons to Kill Yourself
column3: Vitriolic humour from the former double Edinburgh Comedy Award nominee.
Reggae and dub four-piece.
Step back in time with a brand new edition of the popular touring show, and hear rock'n'roll hits from the 50s, 60s and 70s.
Ian Dury's redoubtable band return to pay tribute to their late, great frontman.
The Tannahill Weavers' arrangements blend the beauty of the traditional melodies with the power of modern rhythms.
Americana from the Nashville singer-songwriter.

The pre-eminent dance company celebrate their 20th anniversary with latest piece, Burning. The Dante Sonata of Franz Liszt is played live onstage by Amit Yahav, a young pianist rapidly making an international name.
The Killers frontman tours his indie solo sounds.

column2: Luisa Omielan: Am I Right Ladies?
column3: The comedian with a follow-up to her What Would Beyonce Do? show.
Return of one time Mercury Award nominee singer-songwriter Gemma Hayes.
Blue comedy from man branded 'too rude for television'. Never mind the comedy, that patchwork jacket is hardly fit for public consumption.
Country gal from Suffolk with soul and folk leanings.
Doom metal trio from Liverpool.
Eccentric experimental duo, MC Mr Bruce and DJ/producer Mr Chuckles, mixing vintage sounds, electro, swing and drum &amp bass.

column2: RSNO: Classic FM Hall of Fame
column3: The orchestra presents favourites from the Classic FM Hall of Fame, so don't expect the unexpected, but you can be sure of top-class musicianship.

column2: The RSNO Christmas Concert: The Snowman
column3: A family-friendly concert of carols and seasonal tunes, including the now annual screening of Dianne Jackson's 1982 film of Raymond Briggs' The Snowman with live musical accompaniment, because nothing spells 'Christmas' like a magical fable about the transience of life. Christopher Bell conducts.

Big Big Sing is a UK-wide singing project that aims to inspire thousands of people through singing. Join a choir of hundreds for an evening of song, including workshops with inspirational choirmasters. No experience needed.

column2: RSNO: The Music of John Williams
column3: Some classical fans may flare their nostrils at the idea of a concert devoted to the music of the guy who wrote the score for E.T., but from the brutal simplicity of the two-note 'shark theme' in Jaws to the sinister music-box tinkle of 'Hedwig's Theme', the unifying musical motif in the Harry Potter films, Williams always seems to get it just right. Richard Kaufman conducts music from the above, as well as Williams' classic scores for Star Wars and Raiders of the Lost Ark. Any chance of Close Encounters too?
Teen Irish four-piece delving back to the 60s beat groups for inspiration.

Shostakovich's monumentally bleak Symphony No 8 so failed to hit the appropriate note of mindless optimism that was expected of WW II-era Soviet art that the Soviet authorities rather desperately subtitled it 'the Stalingrad Symphony' and claimed it was a memorial to heroic dead this failed to convince even them, and it ended up being effectively banned. One of those who criticised it was Prokofiev, whose Piano Concerto No 2 is performed here by Nikolai Lugansky. Peter Oundjian conducts.

Nicola Benedetti is front and centre for Szymanowski's last major work, the Violin Concerto No 2, which pits lively folk rhythms against modernist orchestral timbres. There's the Scottish premiere of James MacMillan's Little Mass, performed by the RSNO Junior Chorus, and finally there's Berlioz's crazy-awesome Symphonie fantastique. Peter Oundjian conducts.

In a foam-flecked programme of sea-spray-drenched maritimeness, Peter Oundjian conducts two very different works: Debussy's shimmering La Mer and Vaughan Wililams' epic A Sea Symphony, featuring soprano Katherine Broderick and baritone Benedict Nelson.

Rachmaninov's Piano Concerto No 2 was the first of its composer's pieces to be warmly received, and it helped pull Rachmaninov out of a three-year depression and creative block here soloist Boris Giltburg seeks to recreate the magic. There's also Mahler's Adagietto, Tchaikovsky's Capriccio Italien, and Richard Strauss's 'Suite' from Die Rosenkavalier. Jean-Claude Picard conducts.

Brahms wrote his exhilarating Violin Concerto in the Alps and it's paired here with the most popular piece by another mountain-loving composer, Webern's Langsamer Satz, and Mozart's Symphony No 41. Peter Oundjian conducts, and the guest soloist is the young Norwegian virtuoso Vilde Frang.

Tchaikovsky's Romeo and Juliet is famous for its swoony love theme, ironically quoted in TV shows from Columbo to Spongebob, but it's just part of the overall fabric of this romantic masterpiece. There's also Khachaturian's Piano Concerto, featuring the welcome return of solist Xiayin Wang, and Prokofiev's Suite from Romeo and Juliet for those who haven't had enough star-crossed love in one evening. Peter Oundjian conducts.

It's a swirling wellspring of emotions in this concert: Tchaikovsky's romantic Symphony No 5 is accompanied by Brett Dean's dark Viola Concerto, featuring the composer himself raising the curtain is Borodin's 'Overture' to Prince Igor. Peter Oundjian conducts.

There's only one item on the bill for the first concert of the RSNO's 2015/16 season, but you wouldn't want anything else after the shattering experience of a good performance of Mahler's Symphony No 2, an epic journey of death and rebirth. Featured soloists are Valentina Farcas (soprano) and Sarah Connolly (mezzo), with the RSNO Chorus. Peter Oundjian conducts.

Mussorgsky's Khovantchina Overture raises the curtain on Sibelius' Violin Concerto, with the multi-talented Albanian virtuoso Tedi Papavrami (he's also an actor and translator). The season closes on Beethoven's whopping Symphony No 3 'Eroica', in which a new world can be heard coming into view. Emmanuel Krivine conducts.

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: Mozart Piano Concerto 20
column3: The 'Olympie' Overture by Joseph Martin Kraus, who's been called the 'Swedish Mozart', is followed by Mozart's Piano Concerto No 20 featuring the young British-Taiwanese virtuoso Kit Armstrong then there's the 'Intermezzo' from Richard Strauss's Capriccio and finally, Beethoven's spirited Symphony No 1. Clemens Schuldt conducts.

An evening of music by Bach and his distinguished fanboy, Felix Mendelssohn. The 'Overture' to Bach's Suite No 3 is followed by Mendelssohn's Symphony No 3 and Verleih uns Frieden, and to finish the SCO Chorus and director Gregory Batsleer celebrate its 25th anniversary with Bach's rousing Magnificat. Richard Egarr conducts, with Mhairi Lawson (soprano), Daniela Lehner (mezzo- soprano), Andrew Tortise (tenor) and Peter Harvey (baritone).

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: Beethoven Symphony No 5
column3: New Zealand composer Brett Dean's Testament is a tribute to Beethoven. Then there are Mussorgsky's Songs and Dances of Death, performed by Ain Anger (bass) finally Beethoven's best-known work, the Symphony No 5 renowned for its power and exceptional lucidity. Olari Elts conducts.

Jonathan Dove's The Crocodiamond, with a story by Anthony Horowitz, tells the tale of some fiendish jewel thieves, a plucky young girl and a diamond that used to be in a crocodile's stomach. Ideal for ages 4--10.
An audio-visual experience with light, sound and structure combining with top class DJs and live acts. Line-up includes Crazy P Soundsystem, Davie Miller and more.

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: Generations of Bach
column3: The Dunedin Consort's distinguished John Butt conducts music by two generations of Bachs: Johann Sebastian's Suite No 4 BWV 1069, his eldest son Wilhelm Friedemann's Sinfonia in D minor 'Adagio and Fugue' and his second son Carl Philipp Emanuel's Bassoon Concerto in A Minor. Mozart revered CPE Bach as a master, and he himself is represented here by his Symphony No 40.

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: An Evening with Emmanuel Krivine
column3: Guest conductor Emmanuel Krivine presents some favourites, from Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Haydn through Wagner's Wesendonck Lieder featuring the peerless Karen Cargill, via the rapturous Siegfried Idyll, to Schubert's Symphony No 8 'Unfinished'.

Handel's favourite among his own oratorios, Theodora was a flop when it was first performed but it's always had its admirers, and is now increasingly ranked above the over-familiar Messiah. Richard Egarr conducts this tragic drama of Christian virtue, with a redoubtable cast: Stefanie True, Renata Pokupic, Iestyn Davies, Neal Davies, Samuel Boden, the SCO Chorus and its director Gregory Batsleer.

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: Brahms Symphony No 2
column3: Having spent 15 years writing his Symphony No 1, Brahms wrote his second symphony over the course of a single summer, which goes some way to explain its upbeat mood. Here it's with the Manfred Overture by Brahms' great friend Schumann, and the Piano Concerto of Arnold Schoenberg, Brahms' most brilliant 20th century champion. Robin Ticciati conducts with Lars Vogt as the featured soloist.

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: Brahms Symphony No 1
column3: Brahms' Symphony No 1 used to be nicknamed 'Beethoven's Tenth' because its rugged grandeur reminded early listeners of Beethoven's work this annoyed Brahms, who had spent years working on it precisely so that people wouldn't think he'd just knocked it out. Here it's accompanied by its composer's cheerful Academic Festival Overture and Berg's heartbreaking Violin Concerto, featuring Isabelle Faust. Robin Ticciati conducts.

British rock act whose repertoire covers classic TV themes including The Professionals, Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, Bergerac, Black Beauty, The Rockford Files, Curb Your Enthusiasm and Quantum Leap.

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: A Boy was Born -- Music for Christmas
column3: Elizabeth Poston's setting of Jesus Christ the Apple Tree' Britten's A Boy was Born Bach's 'Komm, Jesu, komm' and the chorale prelude 'Nun komm der heiden Heiland BWV 659' Three Christmas motets by Praetorius and Michael Haydn's Ave regina caelorum. The SCO Chorus and Gregory Batsleer are joined by choristers of St Mary's Cathedral and Duncan Ferguson (organ).
French-born guitar virtuoso plays a solo set of rhythm and blues mixed with elements of world music.
Upcoming mainstream pop singer-songwriter who has supported Stereophonics, The Wanted and Westlife's Shane Filan.
Four Utah dads bringing a rock'n'roll style to classical works.
Reformed Glasgow pop-rockers fronted by Sharleen Spiteri have another crack at the whip.
Celebrating the music of The Blues Brothers with a packed revue of blues and soul.
The Irish legends perform with Davey Arthur.
This tribute band recreates 'Mr Blue Sky' et al, probably with a more stable line-up than the real ELO.
The legendary choreographer presents his latest offbeat piece, a re-imagining of Bizet's Carmen.
Celtic ballads from Edinburgh born singer-songwriter Ross Wilson.
The punk legends, fronted by Dave Vanian, zip through their pithy catalogue.
Surreal and energetic sketch comedy and stand-up from the Irish trio comprising Sean Finegan, Conor Mc Kenna and Sean Flanagan.
A presentation and discussion about ways to be involved with Conversations for Change, which aims to make mental health an easier subject for everyday conversation.

The SCO, together with Dr Elaine Kelly of the University of Edinburgh, conductor Emmanuel Krivine and mezzo-soprano Karen Cargill, explore the work of Richard Wagner, including how his personal relationship fed into his composition. (And did they ever.)
John Kitchen explores Bach's Magnificat with musicians of the Scottish Chamber Orchestra, in a day linked to the performance of the work on Thu 28 Apr at The Queen's Hall.
Olivier Award nominee Caroline Horton's play about anorexia and recovery. Ages 13+.
The Edinburgh-born singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist, now based in Newquay, Cornwall, plays soulful and laid back pop-rock.
The Spanish-born singer-songwriter and guitarist plays traditional tunes alongside contemporary songs.

Award-winning Zoe is back with a brand new hour of comedy which takes a sly look at life before dissecting it with razor-sharp wit. This time she's looking at snobbery in the 21st century and how we're all guilty of it.

A re-formed configuration of the veteran Scotrockers whose hits include 'Fields of Fire' and 'In a Big Country'. They are joined on this leg of the tour by special guests Stevie Agnew, Dave Sharp and Simon Hugh.
Workshop full of ideas and inspiration for creative writing.
Creative writing workshop for teens aged 11--18, designed to equip participants with writing ideas, tips and techniques.
The pair from Edinburgh embraces jazz, classical, world and folk with their saxophone and piano.
The flora, fauna and landscapes of North Norfolk and the Scottish Highlands.
Bracelets and necklaces made from paper by Dutch jeweller.
First major solo exhibition in the UK by Scottish artist who's been based in America for several years.
Renowned American soprano Christine Brewer is accompanied by pianist Roger Vignoles.
Powerhouse five-piece blues band from Glasgow and The Scottish Borders.
Improv fun from across the world.
Improv games from different teams competing for off-the-cuff glory.
A chance to sample as many different whiskies as you think you can handle, also promising 'mystery, entertainment, comicality and madcap pioneering.'
Dundonian indie scamps.
The camp face of Chatty Man proves his status as the King of bitchy comedy.
Singer-songwriter/guitarist playing energetic modern blues-rock.

column2: Jenny Eclair: How To Be A Middle Aged Woman (Without Going Insane)
column3: Jenny Eclair is younger than Madonna, but you won't catch her falling down any stairs at the Brit Awards. Her new show is about middle aged and whether you're better off accepting it or fighting to the death.
Big characters and bigger body slams at this family friendly American-style wrestling show featuring stars from the World Wide Wrestling League.
Acerbic wit and dark, deadpan one-liners from familiar telly face Carr.
Theatre experience with a heavy film noir influence, about a young lawyer trying to exorcise his metaphorical demons.
Very timely AC/DC tribute act.
Tribute band to the prolific Hotel California songsters.
Cash tribute from singer/songwriter Clive John.
The Irish comedy star and host of BBC2's Mock the Week returns to with his observational humour in a new show -- Crowd Tickler.
Homage to the rock legends.

A new comedy based on the writings of PG Wodehouse, starring James Lance as aristocratic fool Bertie Wooster and John Gordon Sinclair as his trusted valet, Jeeves, who is called in to help his master play matchmaker in the countryside. Directed by Sean Foley.
The dapper dafty performs to gigantic audiences following his stint as host on Michael McIntyre's Chat Show.
Aka Colin Vearncombe, singer/songwriter best known for 'Wonderful Life' and 'Sweetest Smile'.
Live performance from the singer-songwriter.
Glasgow-based grunge rock duo featuring Cat Myers on drums and Stina Tweeddale on guitar and vocals.
Bass and electro heavy hip hop from Edinburgh threesome who won both the 2014 SAY award and the Mercury Prize.

column2: Stuart David: In The All-Night Cafe
column3: The Belle and Sebastian co-founder discusses his work, In The All-Night Cafe, with Vic Galloway.
Cool and classy local vocalist singing songs from the likes of Rogers &amp Hart to Gershwin and Cole Porter.
The YouTube sensations take their show on the road -- expect a capella / beatboxing and mouth music like you've never heard before.
Following Celeste under the big top as her cast of endearing animals emerge one by one. A charming and engaging first trip to the circus especially for very young children (0--5 years).
Cadenza, founded in 1992, is one of Scotland's leading amateur choirs with a repertoire that reaches from the Renaissance to the present.
Starcatchers and RSNO (SCOTLAND) present a musical performance for wee ones aged 0--2. The relaxed performance includes two violins, a cello, a raccoon and the story of a tree.
Nashville based country singer-songwriter.
Britrockers who sounded anachronistic even back in their 90s heyday celebrate their 20th anniversary.
Scottish Ballet's Cinderella, specially adapted for younger audiences. The show is performed by the company's dancers with live music from the Scottish Ballet Orchestra.

column2: One Night of Elvis: Lee 'Memphis' King
column3: An evening in the company of top Elvis impersonator Lee 'Memphis' King, performing a selection of Presley's hip-shaking greatest hits.
Fierce New Orleans jazz, soul and swing from the Minnesotan blues chanteuse.
Tribute to Jim Morrison's seminal LA rock crew.
High voltage Japanese garage rockers.

A ceilidh, tribal belly dancing, raffle and buffet to celebrate 25 years of Positive Help, which supports adults and children living with HIV and Hepatitis C. Funds raised to towards supporting their work.

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: New Year in Vienna
column3: The Scottish Chamber Orchestra's annual New year concert is always a glittering shindig, but the proceeds go to Marie Curie Cancer Care.

Two works by composers who lived through the Soviet era, Shostakovich's Symphony No 6 and Rodion Shchedrin's Concerto for Orchestra No 1 'Naughty Limericks' and Rachmaninov's Piano Concerto No 3, a piece so big and challenging that at least one pianist felt bad that he hadn't learned it when he was a student and therefore 'too young to know fear'. Boris Giltburg is the soloist here, with Carlos Miguel Prieto conducting.

column2: Record Store Day at Underground Solu'shn
column3: A day to celebrate all things vinyl and the continuing survival of independent Record Shops. The shop opens early offering a first-come-first-served' on almost 550 exclusive vinyl releases only available for Record Store Day. There's live performances from James Yorkston and Randolf's Leap and vinyl DJ sets from Finitribe and Vic Galloway.
Indie, soul and pop by the Fife-born singer-songwriter, Horse McDonald.
Dan Clark, star of BBC3's How Not To Live Your Life, brings his comedy songs and live band on tour.
Buzzsaw guitars and girl group harmonies from this Californian band.
Old school metal, fronted by the Doncaster-born ex-motorcycle racer, James Toseland.
A night of country, pop, Americana and honky tonk blues.
Punk veterans who can still pull off those frustrated teenage sentiments and shine with 'Ever Fallen in Love?'.
The ultimate ladies night featuring some of the best looking boys in an all male glamour extravaganza.
Trio whose EP Lips was released in early 2015.
The official Queen tribute act, assembled by Roger Taylor.
The three siblings (yes they are direct descendants of Cadbury of the chocolate variety) mix trad folk with modern influences.
Rambling folk troubadour.
The original soppy Irish boy band with granny appeal return celebrating 20 years (way to make us feel old, Boyzone) with their BZ20 Anniversary Tour.
Teen singer-songwriter from Blackpool.
Alt.rock with indie and punk vibes from the multi-million selling trio and Brit rock favourites.
Grunge-flavoured rock by the three-piece band from Blackpool.
Soul and R&ampB songsmith known for the 80s hits 'If You Were Here Tonight', 'Criticize' and 'Saturday Love' performs with a full live band.
Buster Bloodvessel and co persist with the comedy ska.
Robert Fripp's pioneering intense psych-rockers return with a new seven-piece, three-drummer line-up.
Akala aka Kingslee Daley, brother to Ms Dynamite, steps up to the hip hop plate in his own right.
Energetic pop rockers.
X Factor singer-songwriter with a light, observational style.
The anthemic Welsh rockers return with a new album Rewind the Film.
The TV choirmaster heads out on tour.
AKA Peter Wilson from Belfast, who has impressed the White Stripes and the Hives with his gramophone-backed after-hours balladeering and jaunty piano pop.
Street dance skills from the winners of the third series of Britain's Got Talent who actually, believe it or not, have some of the aforementioned talent.
The master of surreality airs his qualms and doubts about the world via a charming blend of religious dubstep, horntallica and an interesting new musical take on Downton Abbey.
Indie and alt.pop by the band with members from Cheltenham and Birmingham.
Spoken word from the slam poetry champion who straddles the gap between performance poetry and pop.
Big boisterous rock from the nicest man in music and former Nirvana sticksman Dave Grohl and co.
The three-piece from Newfoundland, Canada, performs a mixture of original and traditional folk with three-way harmonies.
Super smooth Roxy Music vocalist tours his latest album Avonmore.
He's calling it a solo tour but the brooding singer is accompanied by a backing band of current and former Bad Seed members.
Magician and illusionist in the David Blaine mould.
Moore is one of Ireland's leading solo artists, mixing traditional song with contemporary social and political commentary.
The housewives' choice returns with his variety show mix of pop hits, West End numbers and general campery.
A selection of the best-loved songs from new and classic West End shows like The Phantom of the Opera, Mamma Mia, The Lion King and Les Miserables.
Chilled and eclectic deep house and electronica five-piece.
Sex Pistols tribute outfit (if you hadn't guessed).
Bryan Ferry and his art rock outfit have their hits performed by a world class ensemble with tributes to Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, Eddie Jobson, Paul Thompson and John Gustafson.
An adventure with Wilma and William as they journey to find the elusive worm species. For ages 3 --7.
For those about the rock, AC/DC tribute band.
Seventies rockers and one-time MTV faves (back when MTV played music), best known for hit 'She's a Beauty'.
A celebration of Rory Gallagher featuring original band members Gerry McAvoy and Ted McKenna and friends.
Glasgow's compelling Krautfolk ensemble.
Guitar instrumentals from ex-El Hombre Trajeado man.
Manchester-based based artist Claire Brentnall's songs come backed by strings, synth and piano.
Acclaimed Northumbrian singer-songwriter drawing comparisons to John Martyn and Captain Beefheart.
Come and sing Haydn's Creation with the Scottish Schools Orchestra Trust.
Scottish Ballet's festive production of the classic rags-to-riches fairy tale, set to the unmistakable score penned by Prokofiev, which is performed by the Scottish Ballet Orchestra.
Edinburgh's long-running underground techno party.
A mix of Western ballet and traditional Zulu song and dance with live music from Ladysmith Black Mambazo.
One of the UK's premier blues bands takes to the stage with a fusion of west coast swing and Chicago south side blues.
Former frontman of cosmic cowboys Green on Red for whom 'all roads lead to Dylan'.
Folk rock and melodic indie synth pop.
Liverpool singer-songwriter mixing folk, rock and country.

column2: Carla Bozulich and Don The Tiger
column3: Art-punk provocateur Carla Bozulich is accompanied by underground Spanish musician, Don the Tiger.

Join the UK's largest women-only fundraising event and walk, run, jog or dance 5 or 10k to raise money for Cancer Research UK. The 5k event is suitable for all levels of ability and Race For Life provide you with a training plan and sponsorship pack to get you started.
UK rock veterans and twin guitar pioneers.
Acoustic indie-folk duo Mathias Kom and Ariel Sharratt from Canda.
Old school funky hip hop invested with humour and intelligence.
Stone Roses tribute act officially approved by Roses bassist Mani.
Folky sounds from London five-piece.
A multi-sensory show full of magical ingredients. Three bakers are creating a specially ordered cake when a hungry mouse sneaks in and causes havoc. Ages 3--7.
Aelred (tenor) performs classical contemporary songs.
Ex-Love and Money man ploughs a folkier furrow with his solo career.
Blending double bagpipes, whistle, fiddle, song and Scottish stepdance with Celtic flair and frenzy.

column2: University of Edinburgh Latin American Forum: How Sustainable is Latin America?
column3: A forum exploring sustainable business practices in Latin America, with world-class guest speakers and panel talks.
Bon Jovi tribute act.

column2: Step It Up Dance: Easter Camp
column3: Teaching kids various styles of urban dance, how to create their own graffiti t-shirts and canvases. There's also a visit from an ex-professional rapper, who is there to teach rap and beatboxing.
Wiff Waff run club nights for those of you who want some extra time to work on backhand and topspin.
London-based hard-edged brand of rock and metal quartet.
Tribute to the classic songs of the Fab Four by another group of musicians from Liverpool.
Madchester veteran indie rockers of 'Sit Down' fame stand up once again for a night of reworked Britpop classics.
Blues-rock by the veteran singer-guitarist and band.
A celebration of dance featuring over 120 professional performers. Choreographed by Murray Grant.
An opportunity for mums and dads to buy and sell nearly-new baby and kids' (ages 0--9) items of good quality. Book a stall to sell or turn up on the day to grab a bargain.
Folk, ballads and airs from guitarist/singer McLennan.
Alt.blues guitarist Arcari performs from his back catalogue.
The Americana-influenced Scottish singer-songwriter performs tracks from his latest album Into The Sea.
A summer school in painting and drawing. Classes, workshops and short courses are all available.
Learn how to create found poems and present them in a crafty way.

Massed bike ride from the Meadows down to the Scottish Parliament at Holyrood to raise awareness of the need for proper provision for cyclists on our roads. Come one, come all (even those who don't own a bike) to help make some noise for road safety and follow it all up with a picnic in Holyrood Park.

column2: Patrick Monahan: Adventures in Monahan Land
column3: Playful, interactive comedy from the Irish/Iranian star of Splash! and Show Me the Funny.
The Flaming Lips bring their cosmic eccentric live show, furry animals and fake blood back to the UK.
Unicorn Theatre present a modern telling of Shakespeare's play that explores the way power can lead to conflict. Ages 8+.
De Dansers use live music and invigorating dance to tell the story of children living in a war zone. Suitable for ages 6--11.
A longer walk focussing on the rich archaeological history of Holyrood Park - enjoy the chance to get out and about and benefit from the expert knowledge of a park Ranger. Booking essential.
Discover what life was like in Holyrood Park 2000 years ago, when it was home to Celtic tribes, on this 3-hour guided walk. Booking essential.

Criss-cross your way across the city as an individual rider or as part of a team, and check out the sites of the city all bathed in glorious moonlight on a 50-mile course beginning and ending at Holyrood Palace. Ride for the charity of your choice. Children ages 14--17 can take part with an accompanying adult.
Brutal death metal and grindcore form France.
Traditional setting of Puccini's opera mixing true love, torture and treachery.

column2: Nutrition and Cooking Class -- The Power of Food for Diabetes Prevention and Treatment Class
column3: Dietary class for diabetics and those concerned about diabetes. Featuring cookery demonstrations, food samples and more.
Lo-fi folk meets art rock.
Angular rock from the Guildford-based band.
The Scottish Fiddle Orchestra is the country's foremost large ensemble for traditional music.
Prolific young singer-songwriter from Oxfordshire whose style is strongly influenced by Bob Dylan, Tom Waits and Joni Mitchell.
Indie folk and feedback from Trapped Mice.
Popular Irish folk duo whose career spans over 40 years and 30 albums.
Extracts from classic opera from much respected countertenor Daniels.
Dark, literate, folk noir quintet from Wales.
A cast of actors and musicians sing and tell their stories of searching for gold in America and longing for the land they left behind. Accompanied by live bluegrass music. Ages 10+.
Told with hands and clay characters the show follows a small hero and his desire to escape from the window of a pottery shop.
Waves tells the story of  young Australian Elizabeth Moncello, the unofficial inventor of the butterfly stroke, who copied the fish, penguins and dolphins. Suitable for ages 8+.

A dark fairytale about losing and finding things. When a young boy falls into a fantastical new world he discovers all the things people have lost. Presented by award winning theatre company, Tortoise in a Nutshell. Ages 9+.
Illicit Ink's narrative-focused spoken word event offers an unusual set-up: a crew of writers and performers work together to create an ensemble story with a complete narrative arc.
A literary-flavoured cabaret night, boasting spoken word, 'live literature', new music and dancing into the wee small hours. Hosted by Jenny Lindsay and Rachel McCrum.
Clydebuilt Puppets takes the classic story of Goldilocks and those much put-upon bears and gives it a healthy eating spin. Ages 3+.
Indie rock from the Caithness-based band.
Son of Dave is the harmonica-touting Benjamin Darvell, formerly of Crash Test Dummies, who kicks up a raw blues dust storm all on his lonesome.
Irish folk by the well-established band who were formed in County Donegal in 1987 by lead vocalist Mairead Ni Mhaonaigh.
DJ known for her encyclopedic knowledge of Latin freestyle, Italo, rap and R&ampB.
The amateur choir performs at least two concerts every year, one of which is normally dedicated to Bach.

Haydn was inspired to write The Creation when he went to London and heard the oratorios of Handel. Christopher Hogwood was originally booked to conduct, but with his untimely death in 2014 the baton has been placed in the very able hands of Harry Christophers. With guest soloists Sophie Bevan, Andrew Staples, Markus Werba and the SCO Chorus.
The Edinburgh Youth Orchestra has been offering young musicians practical experience for over 50 years, culminating in concerts in major venues across the nation.
The ensemble plays horn quintets by Mozart and James MacMillan.
The successful Norwegian writer discusses his new thriller Blood On Snow and the popular Harry Hole series.
Comics, cosplay and a whole host of talent and traders at this event, which is now in its second year. Guests include Ryan Browne, Tanya Roberts, Dan McDaid and Iain Laurie.

column2: Roy G Hemmings Motown Hits Show
column3: A celebration of timeless Motown and soul songs from the longest serving member of The Drifters.
Writing, images and artifacts related to the proliferation of the textile industry in Scotland and how it affected witch hunting in the seventeenth century.
Student musicians showcase of classical, jazz and traditional music.
Rugs created as part of a collaboration between Dovecot Studios and the photographic artist.
From Coates to Ellis and from Wood to Sullivan, light music is enduringly popular and the Edinburgh Light Orchestra gives regular concerts celebrating this evocative repertoire.
Detroit-born post-punk pop singer, best known for her bonkers 80s hit 'Lucky Number'.

column2: Edinburgh University Music Society Summer Concert
column3: The society's symphony orchestra, sinfonia, and chorus join forces for a summer musical extravaganza.
Conducted by Morvern Bell.
Apocalyptic US noiseniks

St Mary's Music School is Scotland's specialist independent music school for young people aged 9--19, where musically-gifted students get special instruction as well as a general education. As part of the curriculum, various configurations of student musicians give regular public performances.
The young Brit signee to Erol Alkan's Phantasy Sound label comes to Scotland.
Bach's incisive set of keyboard variations, as arranged for a string ensemble by Dmitry Sitkovetsky.
Formed in 2012, the ensemble specialises in baroque music.
Folky indie rock five-piece from Edinburgh.
The Consort plays Handel's Coronation Anthems and Organ Concerto Op 7 No 1, plus Purcell's Hail, bright Cecilia!
The Chapter House Singers are an amateur choir based at St Mary's Episcopal Cathedral in Edinburgh, singing regular services at the cathedral and performing two concerts a year in the capital.
Now featuring only one member From the Jam. Bruce Foxton is joined by Russell Hastings and drummer Steve 'Smiley' Barnard on their 'The Public Gets What The Public Wants' tour.
Award-winning and prolific folk singer, songwriter and fiddler from Derbyshire, with five albums under her belt before turning 30.
Six-week life drawing class for all ages.

A sponsored nocturnal power walk to raise funds to combat breast cancer. As an added bonus, all participants are invited to walk in their bras (and that includes the men). This year, there's an Alice in Wonderland theme.
The NYOS Junior Orchestra, formerly the National Children's Orchestra of Scotland, is the junior ensemble of the National Youth Orchestras of Scotland and is open to children aged 8--13.
A night of dancefloor classics, retro rock and disco from across the decades stretching from the 60s to last week. All proceeds will be donated to Scottish Autism.

Fundraiser in support of the Leith Theatre Trust and their work to restore and reopen Leith Theatre as a multi-function venue. Includes live music from The Black Diamond Express and Miracle Glass Company.

Edinburgh's world-famous Hogmanay celebration ushers the new year in with a bang. A Torchlight Procession winds through the historic Old Town and onto a son et lumiere on Calton Hill on 30 Dec, a massive street party with live music that culminates with Midnight Fireworks from the ramparts of Edinburgh Castle and 'Auld Lang Syne' on 31 Dec, and for those brave souls still wanting more, there's the Loony Dook (in the River Forth) on 1 Jan.

This community-run music festival returns with folk and classical concerts, workshops and a distinctly family-orientated feel. The 2014 festival featured performances from Balerno Theatre Company, the Pentland Singers and folk courtesy of Real Time, George Duff and Kevin Macleod. The Church Hall acts as a social hub for the weekend, with refreshments on offer all day and suppers in the evening.

World music, dance, fashion, food and fun spread over four areas: the Main Music Stage, the Mela World Dance Feste (newly established in 2012), the Mela Mix stage and the Mela Kidzone. The Mela Global Food Village is on hand to replenish your energy after taking in all the sights and sounds.
A festival incorporating runway shows and glam afterparties, plus more intellectual talks on fashion-linked topics.

MagicFest pulls another rabbit out of the hat with a programme of close-up conundrums, mindboggling illusions, comic cabaret and other feats of the impossible. The festival features workshops as well as shows and ends with the illustrious Closing Gala, a fast paced performance of illusion, sleight of hand, circus and mind reading.
Glam metal and hard rock from the veteran American band founded by singer Donnie Vie and bassist Chip Z'Nuff.

A modern interpretation of the ancient fertility festival of Beltane in the spectacular setting of Calton Hill. Beltane Fire Society performs the story of the death of winter and the birth of summer via dance, drumming, debauched acrobatics, giant-puppetry and fire.
Hands-on science for adults, children and families in venues across the city with programme ranging from the entertaining to the controversial and, of course, the icky.

column2: Magne Furuholmen: Peeling A Glass Onion
column3: Solo exhibition of works by Magne Furuholmen.
Irish traveller songs from McCarthy.
A chance to indulge in the world of comics, superheroes and graphic novels with stalls offering back issues, books and merchandise as well as a number of special guests.

Hosted by Beltane Fire Society, the Samhuinn Fire Festival celebrates the Celtic New Year, marking the end of summer and welcoming the onset of winter. It takes the form of a stunning torchlit procession down the Royal Mile, with acrobatics, fireworks, beautiful costumes and breathtaking performances.
Work by Edinburgh-born illustrator whose work has appeared in the New York Times and publications by the V&ampA and Random House.

column2: Scottish Pole Dance and Fitness Convention
column3: Experienced fitness teachers help you improve your strength and flexibility, whatever your skill level.
Pole dancing competition open to all levels of performer, with age categories from 16 up. Spectators are welcome, too, but will have to pre-book.
One of the country's most popular crossover singers returns to the stage.
A weekend packed full of top local and visiting comedians to tickle your funny bone in an entirely appropriate way.
Edinburgh's festival season kicks off with the Meadows Festival, which offers a local band line-up, dance groups, quirky performers and workshops amidst lots of family-friendly activities.

Scotland's international festival of performing arts for children and young people presents a selection of shows from Scotland and across the world, from storytelling to puppetry, suitable for anyone with an imagination.

Science and gastronomy converge at this foodie mini-fest organised by Edinburgh International Science Festival. Food producers, chefs and mixologists help sciencey types explore the experiences of taste, disgust, pleasure and other aspects of consumption through demos, workshops, exhibitions and discussions.
The Clarsach Society presents an afternoon of festive carols and readings.
Discussing the life and work of Edwin Morgan through his letters, which are collected in a new volume.
Punk/metal band from Carlisle.
Stoner and desert rock by the three-piece band from West Virginia.
Powerful melodic rock and metal.
A look at recent developments in Hungarian glassware.
An eclectic and experimental night of poetry, performance and spoken word, held on the second Friday of each month.
An evening festival to celebrate delicious fermented grape juice, with over 100 different wines on hand to taste. Tickets are redeemable against a case of wine.
You are spoilt for choice at this beer fest, with over a hundred craft bottled beers from across the globe. Tickets available from the Grog shop or warehouse.
Acoustic open mic session.
Folk from the Fife musician.
Upcoming outfit influenced by lo-fi US guitar rock from the 90s.
Seascapes from Arbroath-based painter, her first solo exhibition in Edinburgh.
Nature-inspired images by painter from Crieff.
The Edinburgh Singers were founded in 1952, and is one of the most skilled choirs in the country.
Ska and punk and everything else from Massachusetts.

column2: AL Kennedy in Conversation with Jenni Fagan
column3: Author AL Kennedy takes part in a reading and conversation with Edinburgh University Writer in Residence, Jenni Fagan.

column2: Jane Alexander: The Last Treasure Hunt
column3: The launch of The Last Treasure Hunt, the debut novel from Edinburgh author, Jane Alexander.
Weekly night of local upcoming bands.
Novelist Alexander McCall Smith talks to David Robinson about his Edinburgh writings.
Open mic for literature and spoken word lovers. Email ahead for a chance to perform, or just watch and admire.
Energetic world music from all corners, incorporating samba, gypsy polka, carnival anthems, Slavic waltzes and calypso.

column2: Eugenie Vronskaya: Still Spot in a Turning World
column3: Paintings by the acclaimed Edinburgh-based Russian artist of the household around her.
New work with an estuarine theme.
Old-time country and folk from this young duo whose debut album so impressed BBC Radio 2's Bob Harris that he invited them to record a session.

column2: Romina Ressia: Hide & Seek -- exploring modern identities
column3: Work by striking Argentinian photographer who provides vivid images of concealment and vulnerability, and witty riffs on classical visual culture.
Explore the magical otherworld of Scotland's selkies, fairies, premonition and enchantment with Christina Stewart's traditional songs in Scots, Gaelic and English.

Regular open sessions for all abilities with Edinburgh's own friendly and inclusive lesbian, gay, transgender and bisexual badminton group. It's a fun and easy sport to pick up, with plenty of punning opportunities to boot.
Robert Lindsay and  Rufus Hound star in this West End production, based on the 1989 film.
Metalcore mixed with old school punk.
Minimalist paintings.
Classes teaching babies, toddlers and young children to swim whilst keeping new parents fit and active.
Bluesy Australian singer-songwriter with more than a touch of soul.
A captivating and energetic performance of Japanese Taiko drumming from a company with 20 years on the road.
A two week project covering everything from scene development to prop-making, culminating in a public performance on the final day. Suitable for ages 10-18.
Textile art from Edinburgh-based artist.
Californian hard rock veterans Y&ampT (Yesterday &amp Today) have sold four million albums in their time.
A two day health, fitness and nutrition event with exhibitors, masterclasses from industry experts, a nutrition zone, competitions and demonstrations.
Shona presents brand new material featuring live looping, electronics, flute and vocals.

This unique event draws crowds (and performers) from all over the world with massed pipes and drums, massed military bands, display teams, dancers and the haunting lament of the Lone Piper set against the magnificent backcloth of Edinburgh Castle.

The largest arts festival in the world and the greatest show on earth. Every year thousands of performers take to a multitude of stages all over Edinburgh to present shows for every taste. From big names in the world of entertainment to unknown artists looking to build their careers, the festival caters for everyone and includes theatre, comedy, dance, physical theatre, musicals, operas, music, exhibitions and events.
Stockbridge gets their party hats on for this week-long festival, including ceilidhs, food &amp drink markets, poetry readings, workshops, cookery demos and one big closing party.
Distinguished teacher, composer and harpist in recital.

column2: Live Music Now: Grainne Brady and Ryan Murphy
column3: Brady (fiddle) and Murphy (uilleann pipes) play Irish traditional music.
Cheer on the teams in the UK's largest professional cycling event. In 2015, Edinburgh hosts two stages.
A quirky wee one-dayer where all you budding Bake Off-ers can create a map of Edinburgh made entirely out of cake. Educational . . . and delicious.
This bluesy four-piece perform classics from legends such as BB King, Muddy Waters and Elmore James.
Chrysalis festival offers a new performance opportunity for Scotland's youth theatre sector, with four selected shows being performed twice over two days.
Contemporary folk singer-songwriter performs tracks from his second album House of Jacks.

Massive touring exhibition celebrating the varied history of computer gaming. With more than 125 playable games to work your way through, get stuck into arcade games, physical games (think Dance Battle et al), consoles, PCs and many more. On top of this, there's also displays of concept art, interactive displays and in-depth interviews with game designers.
Tribute to The Beatles.
Recently reformed Edinburgh rockers.
Stars from the West End and Broadway perform songs from some of the country's best-loved musicals.
The harpist, pianist, singer and composer mixes Celtic, classical and world music influences.
Get to grips with a variety of historical weapons of war. Suitable for beginners wear loose and comfortable clothing.
Five days of free readings and discussions plus bookstalls with an emphasis on small and independent presses and writings from outside the mainstream.
The renowned Scottish author returns with his latest novel, A Decent Ride, which follows one his most popular characters -- hustler cabbie Terry Lawson (Juice).
Grunge/funk rock from Berwick-Upon-Tweed.
Country folk singer/songwriter born in Washington DC and based in Austin, Texas, who cut his teeth busking in Ireland.
The Glasgow vocalist best known for being a member of 4AD supergroup This Mortal Coil launches her first solo album Diary of a Lost Girl.
The Cheltenham-based band plays thunderous thrash metal.

Those cuddly fellas at the Bear Scots once again welcome 'bears, cubs, chasers, otters and admirers' for a weekend of furry fun at the largest bear event in Britain. The festival includes multiple parties and club nights, brunches and the crowning of Mr BearScot.

Set up after the Make Poverty History march in Edinburgh during the 2005 G20 meeting, the festival aims to raise the profile of international justice and development issues with a series of talks and events.
Michelin starred and award-winning chefs cook up a storm at this year's festival dedicated to epicureans, as well as offerings from local producers and workshops for food lovers young and old.
Startlingly funny Delaney, who began to take off thanks to his Twitter account, which got him voted 'Funniest Person on Twitter' by Comedy Central.
A unique chance to sample five drams of whisky while enjoying a cruise along the Union Canal.

The bike festival lends a bit of sport to Edinburgh's stacked arts and culture festival calendar. Alongside cycling events, from lengthy scenic tours to talks from well-known cyclists to family bike rides, the festival also features a related film and art programme.
Adelaide-born, NYC-based singer who's worked with Sting and Paul Simon, with her band.

The violinist from Bangalore performs Indian Carnatic music and a variety of contemporary flavours including jazz, Irish folk, electronica, flamenco, blues, pop, Western classical and Bollywood music.

Richard Lewis' adaptation of the award-winning television animation set in a miniature world of fairies, elves and insects. The production features original music by Mani Svavarsson, with original lyrics by Matt Lewis.
Polish rapcore outfit.
Romanian black metal.

RoadBlock Run returns with another race filled with obstacles for runners to navigate in aid of a variety of charities including Chest, Heart and Stroke Scotland. Prizes for fastest males, females and teams, as well as a special prize for runners in fancy dress.

If you've got a head for heights why not abseil off the iconic St John's Church on Edinburgh's busiest shopping street. Raise funds for the Church's building development project or a charity of your choice.
Four-piece instrumental post-rock outfit with math rock and heavy jazz leanings.
Shoegaze and new wave group.

Royal New Zealand Ballet present the tragic story of lovers Giselle and Albrecht and the evil Wilis, merciless spirits of jilted woman who seek revenge on men by forcing them until they die of exhaustion.
A magical story about what it means to be human, featuring robots. From Visible Fictions. Ages 7+.

column2: Craig Hill: Give Him an Inch . . .
column3: High camp buffoonery from the kilted comedian.

Why walk in boring old trousers when you can strut your stuff around the city in a kilt? Choose between six, 13 and 26 mile distances around Edinburgh and help raise funds for children's charities. Entry fee includes an official Kiltwalk t-shirt, goody bag and medal.
The Gilded Balloon are on a mission to keep the spirit of the Fringe alive throughout the year. We approve. They're hosting a handful of hot comedians each Saturday.
An intensive one-day course in the tasting, blending, serving and history of scotch whisky, with a 'Certificate of Expertise' at the end.
The cathedral organist plays a request recital email your requests to the address given.
Smoky-voiced folk singer June Tabor and jazz musicians Iain Ballamy and Huw Warren in their jazz-folk fusion trio.
Improve your writing skills or prepare for exams at this session for 11--18 year olds. Learn grammatical rules from an English teacher and never use a rogue apostrophe again.

Formerly known as the Festival of Spirituality and Peace. Just Festival offers a programme to help people explore their spirituality by engaging with others and promoting peace with live music, talks, dance shows and exhibitions.
The Edinburgh Academy Choir and Choral Society give one joint concert together per year, with guest soloists.

column2: Ludus Baroque: Mass in B Minor
column3: The chamber ensemble presents its annual performance of Bach's masterpiece.
The orchestra plays Schubert's Symphony No 3 and Beethoven's titanic Symphony No 9. Jacek Kaspszyk conducts.
Monthly market selling products by local designers, makers and artists as well as street food. There's even something to keep the dog happy with a stall specialising in cupcakes for dogs.

column2: Les Ballets Trockadero De Monte Carlo
column3: This all-male company present a new show that bridges the gap between farce and classical ballet.
Ros Gasson, founding member of Da Hooley Ceilidh Band, leads a day of tuition in bowing action for the string fiddle.

column2: Michele Ciacciofera: I Hate The Indifferent
column3: First solo show in the UK of this Italian artist concerned with breaking 'the wall of indifference' between the spectator and the work.
Borders-born Kirsty Law performs original pieces influenced by traditional songs, mainly in the Scots dialect, accompanied by Rona Wilkie and Marit Falt.
A hands-on animation and photography club for ages 8--12.
A hands-on animation and photography club for ages 4--7.
Up and coming comedians with a headliner each time.
English vocal folk trio out of retirement for some limited tour dates.
Singer/songwriter/melodeon player Keith Hancock.
Polish singer.
The lead singer of the Ultimate Eagles who has also performed with the likes of Tyketto and Waysted.
Find out about the history of the Royal Observatory Edinburgh and discover more about the night sky.

A celebration of maker culture with exhibits, installations and interactive workshops from all kinds of makers including designers, scientists, artists, crafters and inventors. Meet the makers and get hands on to become a maker yourself.

Images of Scottish people from the collective founded in 2012, comprising Colin McPherson, Jeremy Sutton-Hibbert, Sophie Gerrard and Stephen McLaren. The show is timed to take place one year after the referendum on independence, and is designed to reflect the multiplicity of views and challenges associated with the event.

column2: Grand Cru & Premier Cru Wine Tasting
column3: Master of Wine, Rose Murray Brown leads participants through a tutored tasting of 13 wines including Champagne and Burgundy.
Wine master Rose Murray Brown hosts this tasting, which explores 13 different volcanic wines from around the world.
Learn about the chocolate making process from expert Nadia Ellingham, then taste some of the magical stuff alongside 13 different wines, chosen by Scotsman wine columnist Rose Murray Brown.

column2: Friday Night Champagne v Sparkling Wine Tasting
column3: Rose Murray Brown, who's got an expert nose for wine, serves up 13 paired tastings of the fizzy stuff to help you develop your palate.
A chance to explore the idea of 'education' beyond traditional institutions.
The indie singer-songwriter from Belfast promotes his triple album release The Stage, A Book &amp The Silver Screen.

column2: All the Young Nudes -- Life Drawing Club
column3: A relaxed life drawing club with music and a bar to aid the flow of inspiration.
A staunchly retro soundtrack of 50s rock, 60s grooves and 70s psychedelia.

column2: Nicola Benedetti: Italy and the Four Seasons
column3: Scotland's most illustrious violinist plays Vivaldi's Four Seasons and Tchaikovsky's Souvenir de  Florence, fronting a world-class ensemble.
Contemporary and traditional folk from this Newcastle trio.

If there had been no David Bailey, Austin Powers would have had to invent him. The great British celebrity photographer of his era, Bailey has taken numerous iconic portraits over a 50-year career. This touring exhibition features over 250 portraits, arranged thematically.

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: Barber Violin Concerto
column3: Joseph Swensen (violin) conducts and plays mid 20th century masterpieces: Barber's Violin Concerto Britten's exuberant Variations on a theme of Frank Bridge Swensen's own arrangement of Prokofiev's Five Melodies and Stravinsky's Dumbarton Oaks concerto, which has been likened to 'the Brandenburg Concertos on speed.'

column2: Scottish Chamber Orchestra: Garden of Devotion
column3: Sibelius'  Pieces from 'Kuolema', including the celebrated 'Valse triste' Rolf Martinsson's song cycle based on poems by Tagore, Garden of Devotion, featuring Swedish soprano Lisa Larsson Haydn's Scena di Berenice and Symphony No 86 in D 'Paris'. Olari Elts conducts.

column2: RSNO: The Golden Age of Film Music
column3: Richard Kaufman conducts selections of music from classic Hollywood films by such composers as Alex North (Spartacus), Bernard Herrmann (North by Northwest), Elmer Bernstein (The Magnificent Seven), Max Steiner, (Gone with the Wind) and others.

Elgar's mighty 1900 choral work features Sarah Connolly (mezzo-soprano), Toby Spence (tenor), Alan Opie (baritone) and the RSNO Chorus. Peter Oundjian conducts the finale of the RSNO's 2014/15 season.
After a couple of bracing snifters (Delius A Song for Sunrise and Berg's Seven Early Songs, with soprano Erin Wall) Sir Andrew Davis leads you up the mountain that is Mahler's Symphony No 4.
Peter Oundjian conducts Berlioz's Le carnival romain and Lalo's Symphonie espagnole, featuring soloist Ray Chen (violin), followed by Brahms' exhilarating Symphony No 2.

Robert Schumann bookends a programme of lush romanticism with the Overture, Scherzo and Finale Op 52 and Symphony No 1, plus Wagner's tender Siegfried Idyll and Liszt's Piano Concerto No 2, featuring the acclaimed young Georgian virtuoso Khatia Buniatishvili. Christoph Altstaedt conducts.
